paragraphs.text: Starting is the most important part and the biggest hurdle that most people are facing. They’re pondering and strategizing instead of making. They’re debating what’s going to happen when they haven’t even looked at what’s in front of them.
paragraphs.name: fa10

paragraphs.text: Documenting your journey versus creating an image of yourself is the difference between saying “You should…” versus “my intuition says…”. Get it? It changes everything. I believe that the people who are willing to discuss their journeys instead of trying to front themselves as the “next big thing” are going to win.

Documenting your journey versus creating an image of yourself is the difference between saying “You should…” versus “my intuition says…”. Get it? It changes everything. I believe that the people who are willing to discuss their journeys instead of trying to front themselves as the “next big thing” are going to win.

But, one of the biggest mistakes people make when creating content for their personal brand is trying to oversell themselves because they think that’s what’s going to get people’s attention. Whether you’re a business coach or motivational speaker or artist, I think it’s much more fruitful to talk about your process than about the actual advice you “think” you should be giving them.
paragraphs.name: 12c6

paragraphs.text: This is huge so many people try to be (read: portray) what they’re not, in an effort to grow their brand and often times it backfires or most people can see right through it. Your brand has a personality of itself (I touched on it in my recent post), and if your brand’s personality and your personality is not congruent it can draw a few side-eyes.

paragraphs.text: Hey Gary… my biggest take away from the video is that everyone needs to figure out who they are and what works for them. No argument that your method works for you. It fits who you are and your personality. The methods that work for you aren’t Seth Godin’s methods, or Liz Gilbert’s, or Steven Pressfield’s… I could go on, but you get the point.

f94bd1ab14ed.title: Funnily enough, this goes for brands and companies too.

paragraphs.text: Funnily enough, this goes for brands and companies too. I’ve written in the past about the concept of the ‘vulnerable job posting’ which, rather than creating a grandiose story about how much the company is growing, actually just documents that Steven, their top sales guy left to take care of his kids. There’s SO MUCH value right through the employment chain if that initial documentation is there.
